dataset.title: Continuous plankton recorder zooplankton and phytoplankton data, North Pacific Ocean: 1997, 2000-2009, 2012

associatedParty.organizationName: The National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis (NCEAS)

abstract.para:
The data were collected to describe the plankton populations of the North Pacific and to monitor their distribution and abundance over multiple years. The data include abundances of phytoplankton and zooplankton taxa retained by the Continuous Plankton Recorder which collected plankton samples as it was towed behind a merchant ship on a great circle transect from Vancouver, Canada to Japan. Several transects were occupied during 1997, and 2000-2009. 2009 data are also from a transect from Juan de Fuca Strait to Cook Inlet. The samples each represent 18.5km of tow and have been processed according to routine CPR protocols as directed by the Sir Alister Hardy Foundation for Ocean Science (SAHFOS) which operates and maintains the CPR survey. The midpoint of each sample is allocated a position and time based on information on deployment and recovery times from the ship's log.
1997 and 2000 - 2007 data were provided from archives of the Exxon Valdex Oil Spill Trustee Council. 2008 - 2009 data were provided by the North Pacific Research Board. 2012 data was provided by the PI Sonia Batten.

keywordSet.keyword: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council

section.title: Standard CPR Methodology
section.para: The CPR is towed behind the ship at a depth of about 7m. The plankton are collected continuously but then sectioned into 18.5 km samples (10 nautical miles), each of which has filtered approx 3m3. In the Pacific we process every 4th sample (because of funding limitations) except on the Alaskan Shelf where all samples are processed. Intermediate samples are archived and available for further analyses. We identify and count the zooplankton and larger hard shelled phytoplankton. The phytoplankton data are semi-quantitative and are only a part of the community as not all cells are preserved by formalin, and many are too small to be retained by the 270 um mesh.

The data record contains categories of abundance for 4 analysis stages: Phytoplankton Colour Index (PCI), Phytoplankton taxa, Zooplankton traverse taxa (small zooplankton typically <2mm) and Zooplankton eyecount taxa (large zooplankton typically >2mm). These categories can be converted into abundances per sample according to the tables of accepted values below. Some taxa are recorded for interest by specialists, but not quantitatively, and are labeled “non-routine”. These data should not be used in any quantitative analyses.

After cutting the towed mesh into the discrete samples they are viewed under a microscope. Twenty fields of view are examined across the sample and phytoplankton taxa are counted as a presence or absence in each. The rationale being that an organism is relatively more abundant if it is recorded in 10 fields or so rather than 1. Equivalent numbers of cells per sample are then calculated for 10 categories of abundance (seen in 1 or 2 fields = category 1, in 3 or 4 fields = category 2 and so on up to 19 or 20 fields = category 10) but these data are still best used as relative abundances. Approximate cell numbers per sample can be assessed according to the table below (see also Robinson and Hiby, 1978).

The Phytoplankton Colour Index is a record of the greenness of the mesh as one of 4 colour categories (0, 1, 2, 3) and has been shown to relate to the chlorophyll content of the water, including organisms not visible in the sample (see Raitsos et al., 2013). Category 3 has 6.5 times as much chlorophyll, on average as category 1, while category 2 has twice as much chlorophyll, on average, as category1.

Taxonomic resolution of zooplankton varies, most copepods are identified to species, certainly to genus, and sometimes to stages. 1, 2 or 3 organisms are recorded as Category 1, 2 or 3 respectively while between 4 and 11 individuals in the sample are recorded as Category 4, 12 to 25 as category 5, 26 to 50 as Category 6 and so on up to Category 12 (2001 to 4000). "Accepted values" are then recorded being the mean abundance if 100 examples of each category were accurately counted so that the accepted values given are; 1, 2, 3, 6, 17, 35, 75, 160, 310, 640, 1300, 2690 for categories 1-12. Furthermore, organisms smaller than 2 mm (analysis stage = zooplankton traverse) are counted in a subsample that represents 1/49 of the whole sample, so accepted values are multiplied by 49 to give numbers per sample. Organisms larger than 2mm are not usually subsampled (analysis stage = eyecount zooplankton), unless numbers are very high. From 2010 onwards all zooplankton have been accurately counted and actual counts entered (although the smaller organisms are still counted from a subsample) however, categories are given here for consistency with previous data.

For both phytoplankton and zooplankton "present" in the data record indicates that the organism was seen during sample processing, but not during the counting stage for that organism (e.g. a dinoflagellate seen during the zooplankton traverse). "Present" for a larger eyecount zooplankton usually indicates that the individual was too damaged (e.g. head missing) to count.

Accuracy of taxonomic entities cannot be guaranteed however SAHFOS has a team of analysts and no one person analyses adjacent samples. After analysis adjacent samples are compared and unusual results flagged and checked. Further information on CPR analysis can be found in Batten et al., 2003 and Richardson et al., 2006. Where the taxonomic name of an individual has been revised, the new name has been listed above the original taxonomic entity in the data record to enable comparison with previous years of data.

Position, date and time information of the sample is taken from ship's log information and refers to the midpoint of the 18.5 km sample. Constant speed between log entries is assumed (and in practice this is quite accurate on the scale that the CPR is deployed over since commercial ships tend to run at constant speed between ports).
All categories/abundances given are 'per sample'. Theoretically a sample is 3 cubic metres of filtered seawater, but it isn't actually measured and filtration efficiency can vary.
Table of Accepted Values which can be used to convert the category data into abundances per sample.
category: traverse accepted values: eyecount accepted values

methodStep.instrumentation: The CPR is a relatively simple, rugged piece of oceanographic equipment. It can withstand being deployed from large ships moving at speeds of around 20 knots and still function, and over 95% of tows successfully record plankton. It has the ability to carry instruments to record the physical environment of the plankton which can be invaluable supplementary information when distinguishing between communities. A high level of expertise is needed to carry out the taxonomic analysis but SAHFOS has an excellent team of analysts, some members with over 30 years of experience.

section.title: References Cited
section.para: Batten, S.D., Clarke, R.A., Flinkman, J., Hays, G.C., John, E.H., John, A.W.G., Jonas, T.J., Lindley, J.A., Stevens, D.P., and Walne, A.W. (2003). CPR sampling - The technical background, materials and methods, consistency and comparability. Progress in Oceanography, 58, 193-215.

Raitsos, D.E., Walne, A., Lavender, S.J., Licandro, P., Reid, P.C., and Edwards, M. 2013. A 60-year ocean colour data set from the Continuous Plankton Recorder. Journal of Plankton Research, 35(1): 158-164
Richardson, A.J., Walne, A.W., John, A.W.G.J., Jonas, T.D., Lindley, J.A, Sims, D.W., Stevens, D., and Witt, M. (2006) Using continuous plankton recorder data. Progress in Oceanography, 68, 27-74.
Robinson, G.A. and Hiby, A.R. (1978) The Continuous Plankton Recorder survey. In Sournia, A. (ed.), Phytoplankton Manual. UNESCO, Paris, pp59-63.

project.title: A CPR-Based Plankton Survey Using Ships of Opportunity to Monitor the GOA

funding.para: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council project numbers 02624, 030624, 040624, 070624; North Pacific Research Board (NPRB); Canadian Department of Fisheries and Oceans (DFO); Sir Alister Hardy Foundation for Ocean Science (SAHFOS)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Unique ID assigned to collected sample

D (day) is defined as the time between local sunrise and sunset, while N (night) is defined as the time between local sunset and sunrise. The time of the midpoint of the sample is used to designate the sample as day or night. Its important because the CPR sample is at a fixed depth, but some zooplankton migrate upwards at night, therefore some taxa are only sampled at night. For some statistics you will need to know the proportion of day versus night samples in a particular region and time frame.

Position, date and time information of the sample is taken from ship’s log information and refers to the midpoint of the 18.5 km sample. Constant speed between log entries is assumed (and in practice this is quite accurate on the scale that the CPR is deployed over since commercial ships tend to run at constant speed between ports).

Position, date and time information of the sample is taken from ship’s log information and refers to the midpoint of the 18.5 km sample. Constant speed between log entries is assumed (and in practice this is quite accurate on the scale that the CPR is deployed over since commercial ships tend to run at constant speed between ports).

Position, date and time information of the sample is taken from ship’s log information and refers to the midpoint of the 18.5 km sample. Constant speed between log entries is assumed (and in practice this is quite accurate on the scale that the CPR is deployed over since commercial ships tend to run at constant speed between ports).
CPR identification number assigned to taxonomic entities (http://www.sahfos.ac.uk/data_specieslist.htm)

Microscopic processing stage. Zooplankton counts are recorded for all species and specimen types in each sample. CPR sample analysis is reported for two zooplankton stages: "eyecount" and "traverse". "Eyecount"= zooplankton larger than 2mm; whole sample is checked by eye for presence of species, which are then removed from the sample to be identified under the microscope. "Traverse"= zooplankton smaller than 2mm; sub sample under lower magnification; traverse of the sample is made by microscope, and all individuals are counted.
Indicates phyoplankton or zooplankton being analyzed in the sample

The current revised taxonomic name. Allows samples taken before the name change to be matched with data from after the name change. Otherwise it might appear in a time series that an organism disappeared, and another one appeared, when in fact they are the same.
Species name or specimen type identified in sample, from historic data

The zooplankton abundances are given in categories for eyecount and traverse methods e.g. eyecount category 4 contains between 4 and 11 individuals. Colour= 0, 1, 2, 3 (relates to green colour of the mesh) and phytoplankton= 1-10 (number of fields of view divided by two and expressed as an integer). Sometimes an organism is too rare to be counted in its correct analysis stage but is seen in a subsequent analysis stage. It is recorded as "present" to show that it was there, but not abundant enough to be counted. For full definitions see the Table fo Accepted Values for phytoplankton (_p) and zooplankton (_z).

textDomain.definition: Differing codes depending on analysis stage, see methods and tables of accepted values

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: specimen "present" but not abundant enough to be counted
